thig15.1:14.1: _Bhatti_ “devotion” in this line is followed by _anuratta_ (“loyal”) in the next. The persistence of senses of these words is shown by their occurrence together in the much later Haribhaktikalpalatikā 1.10 (_bhaktānuraktaṁ_).
thig15.1:24.3: The words here are not the normal terms for a mendicant’s possessions. Perhaps these were terms used in a non-Buddhist tradition, or else the author is aiming at poetic effect.
thig15.1:31.4: “Twice-born” (_dvijātī_) is an epithet of brahmins, referring to material and spiritual births. It is normally found only in later literature, and this might be the first recorded usage of the idiom.
thig15.1:43.3: The text is literally “neither woman nor man”. The preceding verses speak repeatedly of castration, making it clear that this means having no genitals, rather than simply being a person who is non-binary.
thig15.1:46.2: For _pattayobbanaṁ_ as “come of age”, i.e. old enough to have sex, see [ja532:80.4]().
thig15.1:46.3: Like an ox in a pen ([an6.60:3.1]()).
